articles.title: Welcome to the TunnelMesh Blog
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: A place for engineering notes, release announcements, and deep-dives on encrypted mesh networking.

articles.title: Introducing TunnelMesh: Encrypted Mesh Networking for the Next Frontier
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: Today we're open-sourcing TunnelMesh — a P2P mesh networking tool built in Go that creates encrypted tunnels between nodes using the Noise IKpsk2 protocol with ChaCha20-Poly1305 encryption.

articles.title: Why We Built TunnelMesh
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: Every side project starts with a frustration. Ours started with a weekend of fighting WireGuard configs, broken NAT traversal, and the realisation that none of the existing tools did exactly what we needed.

articles.title: The Noise Protocol: How TunnelMesh Handles Encryption
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: A practical walkthrough of the Noise IKpsk2 handshake pattern — why we chose it, what it gives us for free, and what the handshake actually looks like on the wire.

articles.title: NAT Traversal: The Dark Art of Making Peers Find Each Other
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: Getting two machines behind NAT to talk directly is harder than it should be. Here's how TunnelMesh does it — and what happens when it can't.

articles.title: Building in Go: What a Month of TunnelMesh Taught Us
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: A month into writing a networking tool in Go — what the language got right, where we hit walls, and the libraries that saved us.

articles.title: ChaCha20-Poly1305: The Cipher Powering TunnelMesh
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: A deep dive into why we chose ChaCha20-Poly1305 over AES-GCM, how AEAD ciphers work, and what the performance profile looks like on the hardware TunnelMesh actually runs on.

articles.title: Docker Integration: Containers as First-Class Mesh Citizens
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: With Docker integration, containers on the mesh get automatic port-forward rules, mesh DNS, and the same zero-trust filtering as bare-metal nodes.

articles.title: NFS Over TunnelMesh: Secure File Sharing Across the Mesh
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: NFS was designed for trusted local networks. TunnelMesh makes the mesh a trusted local network — here's how we use that to share files securely across geographically distributed nodes.

articles.title: Inside the Transport Fallback Chain: UDP, SSH, and WebSocket Relay
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: A technical walkthrough of how TunnelMesh selects, negotiates, and promotes transport paths between peers — and the engineering decisions behind the three-level fallback.

articles.title: New Year, New Mesh: Where TunnelMesh Is Going in 2026
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: An honest look at where the project stands, what's working, what still needs work, and what we're building next.

articles.title: Benchmarking TunnelMesh
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: How does TunnelMesh actually perform? We look at throughput, latency, and CPU overhead across transport modes and hardware — methodology included so you can reproduce the results.

articles.title: User Identity and Zero Trust in TunnelMesh
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: How TunnelMesh thinks about identity — from SSH key derivation to per-user packet filtering — and what "zero trust" actually means in a mesh network you control.

articles.title: The S3 Storage Backend: Sharing Object Storage Across the Mesh
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: TunnelMesh can expose a shared S3-compatible object store to all mesh nodes. Here's the architecture, the use cases it solves, and how to set it up.

articles.title: TunnelMesh in the Wild: Early Deployment Lessons
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: A few months in, TunnelMesh is running on real infrastructure. Here's what we learned from watching it operate outside our own machines.

articles.title: The Internal Packet Filter: Fine-Grained ACLs for Mesh Networks
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: A deep dive into TunnelMesh's packet filter — the default-deny firewall that lives inside the tunnel and gives you per-peer, per-protocol access control without touching the host firewall.

articles.title: Deploying TunnelMesh on AWS, GCP, and Hetzner: A Field Guide
articles.author: TunnelMesh Team
articles.excerpt: Practical deployment notes for running TunnelMesh coordinators and nodes on the three cloud providers we use most — with Terraform snippets for each.
